If computer science were to reach its full and ethical potential, it must recognize that the world of logic, proofs, computation, data, and tech is far more diverse than it currently reflects. The field has an illustrious roster of LGBTQIA+ innovators and thinkers and that history shall always be remembered. The UPV Komsai.Org as a whole are an ally of the LGBTQIA+ community and call for the recognition of their rights to love, to live, and to be themselves.

The UPV Komsai celebrates its LGBTQIA+ members with no reservation. They are some of the most hardworking, talented, brave, and intelligent people an organization could wish to have. The home of the visuals would not look stunning without them, and we strive to be a safe, accepting, and loving space for all regardless of their SOGIE. We strive to be an example to other computer science and IT student organizations when it comes to not just excellence, but also diversity and acceptance.
Pubmat by: Eleah Joy Melchor (BSCS III)
Written by: Drew Cudiamat (BSCS II)

The UPV Komsai.org is one with the international STEM community in celebrating #AdaLovelaceDay.
Today, we look back to commemorate her legacy and honor all the extraordinary women in STEM for their dedication and commitment to the field of science and technology.

A bold and courageous woman herself, Augusta Ada Byron was a British mathematician and the world's first-ever computer programmer. Popularly known as Ada Lovelace, she is one of the pioneers who made a significant contribution to the development of Computer Science.

Her most remarkable work happened in 1843, when she translated an article about Charles Babbageâ€™s Analytical Engine.  Together with her translation, she added her own detailed notes, including an algorithm for the Analytical machine to calculate Bernoulli numbers. This algorithm is considered as the first computer program.  Because of her brilliance, Babbage called her "The Enchantress of Numbers".

Well ahead of her time, she also foresaw countless potential uses of the machine that go beyond mathematical calculations. This laid the foundational groundwork for modern computing. Today, her legacy lives on in every algorithm, every device, and continues to inspire every woman in the tech industry.
Written by: The Education and Research Committee

As The UP Intermedius celebrates its 33rd anniversary, the spotlight turns toward one of our ownâ€”a woman whose talent and artistry has leapt from university halls to lights, lenses, and center stage. Tara kept the passion for theater alive and even expanded to films long after stepping out of the university. Today, her star shines brighter than ever.
Congratulations, Tara Rose Lozano Molina!
